sections.title: Introduction to Chemical Reactions
sections.summary: Exploration of situations where chemical reactions occur in daily life and how to recognize a chemical reaction through observable changes

keyConcepts.name: Chemical Reaction
keyConcepts.description: A process where the original substances change their chemical identity to form new substances

keyConcepts.name: Signs of Chemical Reactions
keyConcepts.description: Observable indicators including change in state, change in color, evolution of gas, and change in temperature

visualElements.description: Setup for burning magnesium ribbon and collecting magnesium oxide

scientificPrinciples.application: The total mass of the elements present in the products equals the total mass of the elements in the reactants

labActivities.title: Burning of Magnesium Ribbon
labActivities.description: Observing the chemical reaction when magnesium burns in air
safetyNotes: Keep the burning magnesium ribbon away from eyes
procedure: Clean magnesium ribbon with sandpaper
Hold with tongs and burn using spirit lamp
Collect the ash in a watch glass
labActivities.expectedResults: Magnesium burns with a dazzling white flame and forms a white powder (magnesium oxide)
analysisQuestions: What happens when magnesium burns in air?

labActivities.title: Reaction of Zinc with Acid
labActivities.description: Observing the reaction between zinc granules and dilute acid
procedure: Take zinc granules in a test tube
Add dilute acid to the test tube
Observe what happens around zinc granules
Touch the test tube to feel temperature change
labActivities.expectedResults: Bubbles form (hydrogen gas) and the container becomes warm
analysisQuestions: Is the reaction exothermic or endothermic?

exercises.question: List four observations that indicate a chemical reaction has taken place

sections.title: Chemical Equations
sections.summary: Methods of representing chemical reactions symbolically through word equations and chemical equations

keyConcepts.name: Word Equation
keyConcepts.description: A way to represent chemical reactions using names of reactants and products

keyConcepts.name: Chemical Equation
keyConcepts.description: A symbolic representation of a chemical reaction using chemical formulas

keyConcepts.name: Balanced Chemical Equation
keyConcepts.description: A chemical equation with equal number of atoms of each element on both sides

visualElements.description: Step-by-step method for balancing chemical equations
visualElements.interactivityHint: Interactive steps to balance sample equations

scientificPrinciples.application: Mass can neither be created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction, requiring balanced equations

examples.content: Balancing the equation for iron reacting with water: Fe + H₂O → Fe₃O₄ + H₂
examples.context: Detailed step-by-step process to balance a complex chemical equation
Example of an already balanced equation

exercises.question: Balance the following equation: Fe + H₂O → Fe₃O₄ + H₂
exercises.hint: Start with the compound containing the maximum number of atoms

sections.title: Types of Chemical Reactions
sections.summary: Classification of chemical reactions based on how atoms and molecules rearrange

keyConcepts.name: Combination Reaction
keyConcepts.description: Two or more substances combine to form a single product

keyConcepts.name: Decomposition Reaction
keyConcepts.description: A single substance breaks down to give two or more simpler substances

keyConcepts.name: Displacement Reaction
keyConcepts.description: A more reactive element displaces a less reactive element from its compound

keyConcepts.name: Double Displacement Reaction
keyConcepts.description: Exchange of ions between two compounds forming two new compounds

keyConcepts.name: Oxidation
keyConcepts.description: Addition of oxygen or removal of hydrogen

keyConcepts.name: Reduction
keyConcepts.description: Removal of oxygen or addition of hydrogen

keyConcepts.name: Redox Reaction
keyConcepts.description: Reaction in which both oxidation and reduction occur simultaneously

labActivities.title: Formation of Slaked Lime
procedure: Take calcium oxide in a beaker
Slowly add water
Touch the beaker to feel temperature change
labActivities.expectedResults: Calcium oxide reacts with water to form calcium hydroxide with heat release
analysisQuestions: Why does the mixture become warm?
What type of reaction is this?

labActivities.title: Thermal Decomposition of Ferrous Sulphate
procedure: Note the color of ferrous sulphate crystals
Heat the crystals in a boiling tube
Observe the color change and odor
labActivities.expectedResults: Green ferrous sulphate crystals change color and produce sulfur dioxide gas
analysisQuestions: What happens to the ferrous sulphate crystals when heated?

labActivities.title: Displacement Reaction with Iron and Copper Sulphate
procedure: Clean iron nails with sandpaper
Immerse nails in copper sulphate solution
Observe for 20 minutes
Compare the color changes
labActivities.expectedResults: Iron displaces copper from copper sulphate solution; iron nails become brownish and blue color of solution fades
analysisQuestions: Why does the color of the iron nail change?
Why does the blue color fade?

labActivities.title: Precipitation Reaction
procedure: Take sodium sulphate solution in a test tube
Add barium chloride solution
Observe the mixture
labActivities.expectedResults: Formation of white precipitate of barium sulphate
analysisQuestions: What is the white substance formed?

keyConcepts.name: Rancidity
keyConcepts.description: The oxidation of fats and oils in food items causing unpleasant smell and taste

everydayConnections.explanation: Iron combines with oxygen and moisture to form iron oxide (rust)

keyVocabulary.definition: A process that involves rearrangement of atoms to form new substances
keyVocabulary.etymology: From Greek 'chemeia' (alchemy) and Latin 'reactio' (action in response)

keyVocabulary.definition: The starting substances in a chemical reaction
The substances formed in a chemical reaction
A reaction that releases heat energy
A reaction that absorbs heat energy
The process of gaining oxygen or losing hydrogen
The process of losing oxygen or gaining hydrogen
The formation of an insoluble solid in a solution during a chemical reaction

commonMisconceptions.misconception: All chemical reactions are fast and visible
commonMisconceptions.correction: Chemical reactions can be slow and may not have visible signs (e.g., rusting)

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Mass is not conserved in chemical reactions
commonMisconceptions.correction: According to the law of conservation of mass, total mass remains the same before and after a reaction

commonMisconceptions.misconception: All reactions that produce heat are combustion reactions
commonMisconceptions.correction: Many types of reactions can be exothermic, not just combustion
In a broader sense, oxidation refers to loss of electrons, which can occur without oxygen
